sen.j: 鎌倉時代に入ると、白河の中心部は「岡崎」と称されるようになり、後鳥羽上皇が承元2年（1208年）に白河に御所を造営した際に「岡崎御所」と称されて（『百錬抄』）以後、岡崎という呼称も用いられるようになる。

sen.j: 京都に旅行へ行ったと嘘をつく人が、この白河（白川）の地について聞かれ川のことだと思い、夜に船で通ったのでよく知らないと答え、嘘がばれたという逸話から、熟睡して前後を知らないことを「白河夜船（白川夜船）」という。
sen.e: Shirakawa yofune (Shira-kawa River yofune) means that someone was fast asleep and totally unaware of what is going on around him, based on an anecdote that someone said he went on a journey to Kyoto, which was not true, and when he was asked about the Shirakawa (Shirakawa) area, he thought it was about Shira-kawa River, so said it was unanswerable because he went through the area by boat at dark night.

Shirakawa yofune (Shira-kawa River yofune) means that someone was fast asleep and totally unaware of what was going on around him, based on an anecdote that someone said he went on a journey to Kyoto, which was not true, and when he was asked about the Shirakawa (Shirakawa) area, he thought it was about the Shira-kawa River, so said it was unanswerable because he went through the area by boat in the dark of night.

Shirakawa yofune' (Sound asleep) means that someone was fast asleep and totally unaware of what was going on around, which is based on the anecdote-- when a lier told that he had been on a journey to Kyoto, and he was asked about the Shirakawa area, he thought he was asked about the Shira-kawa River and told that he was not aware much of the river because he traveled down the river by boat in darkness of night, there, he was caught in his lie.

sen.j: かつては、見たことがないものをさも見たことがあるかのようにしったかぶって言うことの意味にも用いられた。
sen.e: In the past, this term was used to mean know-it-all attitude like acting as if he had seen things he hasn't seen.
In the past, this term was used to mean a "know-it-all" attitude, one acting as if he had seen things he hadn't.
In the past, this term meant a "know-it-all" attitude such as saying as if someone had seen things he hadn't.
